summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office (USAO) personnel discussing opposition to a compassionate release motion filed by inmate Donald Carr. Carr, convicted in the Astramed oxycodone trafficking case, sought release from Fort Dix prison due to COVID-19 risks and hypertension. The emails detail the legal arguments against his motion and reference prior denials by Judge Schofield.

persons.name: Donald Carr
persons.context: Convicted defendant in the Astramed oxycodone trafficking case, serving a 132-month sentence, who filed multiple motions for compassionate release citing hypertension and COVID-19 risks at Fort Dix prison.

persons.name: Judge Schofield
persons.context: Presiding judge over Donald Carr's case who previously denied his compassionate release motions and set deadlines for government responses.

connections.description: Judge Schofield presided over Carr's criminal case, sentenced him, and ruled on his compassionate release motions.

events.title: Initial compassionate release motion denied
events.description: Judge Schofield denied Donald Carr's initial compassionate release motion.

events.title: Third compassionate release motion filed
events.description: Donald Carr, with new counsel, filed a new compassionate release motion citing hypertension and COVID-19 cases at Fort Dix prison.

events.title: Donald Carr begins prison sentence
events.description: Donald Carr began serving his 132-month sentence for his role in the Astramed oxycodone trafficking scheme.

keyFacts: Donald Carr was convicted for playing a substantial role in the Astramed oxycodone trafficking scheme based at a pill mill in the Bronx.
Carr was sentenced to 132 months imprisonment in February 2014 with a projected release date of September 2023.
Carr filed multiple compassionate release motions citing hypertension and COVID-19 risks at Fort Dix prison, all opposed by the U.S. Attorney's Office.
Judge Schofield had previously denied two prior compassionate release motions from Carr in April 2020.
The U.S. Attorney's Office recommended opposing the third motion on grounds of failure to establish extraordinary and compelling reasons and based on 3553(a) sentencing factors.
